GEOPOLITICAL

Furthermore, Macron said he wants to work on a new deal with Iran, while he also stated the Iran deal can be added to but it should not be torn apart and noted that President Trump’s concerns can be taken aboard. (Newswires)


US

US New Home Sales Change MM (Mar) 4.0% vs. Exp. 1.9% (Prev. -0.6%, Rev. 3.6%)


MARKET RECAP

There wasn’t a single specific catalyst for the stock slide on Tuesday, however, a collection of reasons applied pressure, leaving a risk-off taste in the mouth of traders. Worries resurfaced as the US 10-year yield crossed 3%, while the 2-year yield rose above 2.50%. Others cited concerns in the tech sector (AAPL fifth red day on concerns over iPhone demand, while GOOGL weighed after earnings, FAANG’s weak); others cited geopolitical uncertainties. The S&P 500 Emini was consolidating beneath 2700 pre-market, but not even decent numbers from Caterpillar (which lent some premarket strength to the Dow mini) could keep indices bid, and the grind lower was gradual yet persistent, accelerating in the latter part of the session, before basing around 2620. SPX -1.3% at 2634, NDX -2.10% at 6509, DJI -1.7% at 24017.

There was an extraordinary amount of attention on 10-year yields temporarily breaching the 3.00% handle for the first time in four years, as the curve steepened, which also saw yields on 2s above 2.50% at one point. Traders were attributing the rise in yields to the notion that the Fed hikes will take an ‘autopilot’ approach (as was hinted by the Fed’s Williams over the weekend) as well as the increased size of issuance out of the US Treasury, which will auction a total of $113bln this week ($32bln 2-year notes on Tuesday; $35bln 5-year notes on Wednesday; $17bln 2-year FRN on Wednesday; $29bln 7-year notes on Thursday. Net supply is implied at $3.6bln given that $109.4bln maturing at the mid-month settlement. Analysts also note that over the next month, gross supply (including next week’s auction of $73bln in 3s, 10s, 30s) is around $169bln, with large cashflows due, estimated around $208bln. Traders are also cognizant of the Q2 refunding announcement on 2/May, where the US Treasury may raise the size of auction issuance, according to some analysts. Today’s auction of 2s saw a tail of 0.5bps, while the yield at auction was the highest since 2008. The internals weren’t particularly bright, with cover beneath recent averages and direct takedown slightly higher than recent averages.

content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Stocks lower, USD lower, treasuries flat, oil down.
* REAR-VIEW: Macron open to new Iran deal; US consumer confidence and new home sales beat.
* AHEAD:  API inventories (aftermarket); DOE inventories (Weds); ECB speak (unlikely to feature policy comments); Earnings on Weds include AT&T, Boeing, Facebook, Twitter, Qualcomm, Comcast.

* TRADE WARS: US President Trump said that there was a good chance of coming to an agreement with China over trade, once again highlighting his principles of fairness and reciprocity, and talking-up his belief that the current trade arrangement is unfair. Trump will be sending Treasury Secretary Mnuchin to China in the next few days to continue talks with the nation. In NAFTA talks, Canadian Foreign Minister Freeland said intensive NAFTA negotiations were progressing well, and a win-win deal was possible, while reiterating the sensitivities around the auto side of negotiations, which she didn’t specifically make comments on. Mexican policymakers continued to express optimism over reaching a NAFTA agreement, with the head of business lobby CEE making comments that were in line with the timing suggested by US, Canadian and Mexican policymakers last week. Meanwhile, the Mexican economy minister reiterated his optimism, but said that Mexico is unwilling to accept restrictions on steel and aluminium. Elsewhere, EU trade chief Malmstrom repeated the EU’s desire for permanent exemption from US levies, arguing that metal tariffs breach WTO rules.

* GEOPOLITICS: President Trump and French President Macron delivered a press conference that gave both hot and cold signals with regards to the Iran nuclear accord; Trump had earlier suggested that a deal was close, and during the press conference between the two leaders, Macron suggested that he wanted to advance work on a new deal with Iran. However, Trump reiterated that his mind was not made up, and told Iran that if it threatened the US, it would pay a large price (Iran had earlier threatened to pull out of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty if the US pulled out of the nuclear accord). The US must make its decision on whether to pull out of the Iran deal and apply new sanctions on the country by the 12/May. On North Korea, Trump said that denuclearisation of the nation means ‘getting rid of its nukes’.

* DATA: US consumer confidence rose in April to 128.7 against expectations of a decline. However, the Conference board also noted that the percentage of consumers claiming jobs are “plentiful” declined from 39.5% to 38.1%, and those claiming jobs are “hard to get” also declined from 15.7% 15.2%, resulting in a narrowing of the differential between the two to 22.9 in April from 25.0 in March (a higher differential is preferred by economists as a sign of the economy’s health). US new home sales also surprised to the upside in March, bringing the data set in line with other, more optimistic home builder confidence surveys, which are near cyclical highs.

* EQUITIES: SPX -1.36% at 2634, NDX -2.10% at 6509, DJI -1.77% at 24017 SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals:  -1.59%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: -0.61%, Energy: -1.18%, Financials: -0.64%, Health Care: -0.88%, Industrials: -2.59%, Materials: -2.81%, Technology: -2.46%, Telecoms: +0.92%, Utilities: +0.56%.

There wasn’t a single specific catalyst for the stock slide on Tuesday, however, a collection of reasons applied pressure, leaving a risk-off taste in the mouth of traders. Worries resurfaced as the US 10-year yield crossed 3%, while the 2-year yield rose above 2.50%. Others cited concerns in the tech sector (AAPL fifth red day on concerns over iPhone demand, while GOOGL weighed after earnings, FAANG’s weak); others cited geopolitical uncertainties. The S&P 500 Emini was consolidating beneath 2700 pre-market, but not even decent numbers from Caterpillar (which lent some premarket strength to the Dow mini) could keep indices bid, and the grind lower was gradual yet persistent, accelerating in the latter part of the session, before basing around 2620.

SPX was led by Cadence Design systems (CDNS) and Whirlpool (WHR) as CDNS showed a strong earnings report, and WHR, despite missing estimates on EPS & Revenue, said it agreed to sell its Embraco compressor unit to Japan’s Nidec in a $1.1bln deal so it can focus on its consumer business. However, weighing on the index,  Freeport-McMoRan (FCX) closed down ~15% following poor earnings and concerns regarding a new work contract in Indonesia may be delayed due to Indonesia presidential election.

Outperformers in the NDX included Shire (SHPG) following later confirmed reports that Takeda (4502 JT) was offering another provisional offer for SHPG, also Biogen (BIIB) beating EPS expectations among NDX leaders. On the flip side, Alphabet (GOOG) reported earnings after the bell on Monday, which beat on both top and bottom lines but the $3.40 added due to tax benefit was seen as a negative to traders as well as increasing costs and narrowing margins. GOOG closed Tuesday trade among Incyte (INCY) after the FDA suggested the approval of 2mg dose, instead of the 4mg dose for treatment of arthritis in adult patients.

Verizon (VZ) led the DJI on Tuesday following a strong earnings report, and also leading the telecom sector making it today’s outperformer with utilities who gained due to its defensive nature. However, the DJI entered into correction territory following 10yr yields crossing 3.00%, also being hampered by Caterpillar (CAT), who started the day off with a strong earnings report and was an outperformer, but as the conference call took place concerns were raised where the CEO noted Q1 will be the ‘high water mark’ for the year and stated that steel costs will continue to rise which led to all of the recent gains paring back and extending to losses of greater than 6% closing among 3M (MMM) in the DJI as the underperformers as 3M cut its FY EPS forecast.

M&A News today focused on Shire as both Shire and Takeda confirmed a revised proposal was made, but there was no certainty of a firm offer, nor the terms on any potential offers. Also pre market SS&C Technologies (SSNC) stated they do not intend to make an offer for UK’s Fidessa (FDSA LN), and both Cigna (CI) and Express Scripts (ESRX) were asked to hand over additional information to the DoJ. In smaller M&A news, Trimble (TRMB) stated it would acquire Viewpoint from Bain Capital for roughly $1.2bln.

* CRUDE: WTI futures (M8) settle 7 cents higher at 68.40/bbl; Brent futures settle 28 cents higher at 74.06/bbl Crude was supported in the early part of the session as geopolitical tensions continue to simmer in the Middle East. Some analysts also cited production outages in Venezuela, while the Nigerians said crude exports would fall slightly in June to 1.796m BPD. However, there were offsetting factors for the crude complex, which made the air thin for Brent near $75.50 and WTI near $69.50: The Kazakhstan energy minister said output at Kashagan was up to 300k BPD, while repairs to the Libyan Waha pipeline had now completed, after militant attacks over the weekend. The US crude benchmark printed fresh session lows beneath $68/bbl amid the Trump/Macron press conference; it was a wishy washy press conference – Macron suggested that work on a new Iran deal should be advanced, though Trump struck a more belligerent line, warning Iran against making threats to restart its nuclear programme, or face a high price. Trump characteristically left the situation unclear towards the end of the press conference, hinting that his made was still not made up.

* TREASURIES: US 10yr T-Notes futures settle unchanged at 119-10+ . There was an extraordinary amount of attention on 10-year yields temporarily breaching the 3.00% handle for the first time in four years, as the curve steepened, which also saw yields on 2s above 2.50% at one point. Traders were attributing the rise in yields to the notion that the Fed hikes will take an ‘autopilot’ approach (as was hinted by the Fed’s Williams over the weekend) as well as the increased size of issuance out of the US Treasury, which will auction a total of $113bln this week ($32bln 2-year notes on Tuesday; $35bln 5-year notes on Wednesday; $17bln 2-year FRN on Wednesday; $29bln 7-year notes on Thursday. Net supply is implied at $3.6bln given that $109.4bln maturing at the mid-month settlement. Analysts also note that over the next month, gross supply (including next week’s auction of $73bln in 3s, 10s, 30s) is around $169bln, with large cashflows due, estimated around $208bln. Traders are also cognizant of the Q2 refunding announcement on 2/May, where the US Treasury may raise the size of auction issuance, according to some analysts. Today’s auction of 2s saw a tail of 0.5bps, while the yield at auction was the highest since 2008. The internals weren’t particularly bright, with cover beneath recent averages and direct takedown slightly higher than recent averages.

* FOREX: DXY Not strictly dancing to the Treasury market tune and unable to revisit overnight highs just over the 91.000 handle even though UST yields have at last breached key/psychological levels on the upside, ie 10 year touching 3% and 2 year 2.5% ahead of $32bln supply. JPY The clear G10 underperformer, as debt yield differentials and carry plays propel the headline pair through 109.00 and the 100 DMA and then pairing back losses finding support around 108.70. NZDAUD Kiwi still grounded and pressured by the firm Greenback and cross positioning as the AUD holds above 1.0660 resistance and has reclaimed 0.7600+ status vs the USD, albeit just and with fund offers said to be parked up at 0.7620-30. NZDUSD floundering towards the bottom end of a 0.7105-55 range. GBP/CAD/EUR All ending Tuesday’s choppy session firmer vs the USD on a mixture of technical buying, short covering and supportive cross activity to the detriment of the JPY. Cable has bounced off a 1.3920 low that aligned with chart support, but looks offered ahead of 1.4000, while USDCAD has pulled back from 1.2850+ peaks amidst ongoing hopes (some substantiated by latest updates on negotiations) of a NAFTA agreement in the not too distant future. EURUSD has reclaimed 1.2220 after post-Ifo selling stopped short (marginally) of breaching yesterday’s base and is back above the 100 DMA (1.2210).

subject: AUCTION PREVIEW: US to sell USD 32bln of 2-year notes on Tuesday at 1800 BST/1300 EDT
content:
ISSUANCE: US Treasury will auction a total of $113bln this week ($32bln 2-year notes on Tuesday; $35bln 5-year notes on Wednesday; $17bln 2-year FRN on Wednesday; $29bln 7-year notes on Thursday. Net supply is implied at $3.6bln given that $109.4bln maturing at the mid-month settlement. Analysts also note that over the next month, gross supply (including next week’s auction of $73blnin 3s, 10s, 30s) is around $169bln, with large cashflows due, estimated around $208bln. Traders are also cognizant of the Q2 refunding announcement on 2/May, where the US Treasury may raise the size of auction issuance, according to some analysts.

2-YEAR PREVIEW: Since the previous auction cycle, 2-year yields have printed a series of fresh cyclical highs, though parts of the curve have not kept up with the rise in the short-end, resulting in fresh cyclical narrows for the likes of 2s30s. some policymakers have warned that the curve could invert (Fed’s non-voter Bullard suggested it could happen within six-months), which could portend a recession; others, however, note that the cyclical dynamic is different this time given the activist monetary policy that central bank’s engaged in through the great financial crisis, which saw them build bond holdings. Goldman Sachs, for instance, does not see an inversion in this cycle. Either way, this cheapening of the 2s sector on the curve is likely to be a positive for the auction. Elsewhere, recent auction of 2s have been lukewarm, generally stopping through or tailing by +/- 1bps on average over the last six and 12-months. There has also been attention on dealer participation, which has been edging up over the last few auctions amid declining direct and indirect participation.

All ending Tuesday’s choppy session firmer vs the Usd on a mixture of technical buying, short covering and supportive cross activity to the detriment of the Jpy. Cable has bounced off a 1.3920 low that aligned with chart support, but looks offered ahead of 1.4000, while Usd/Cad has pulled back from 1.2850+ peaks amidst ongoing hopes (some substantiated by latest updates on negotiations) of a NAFTA agreement in the not too distant future. Eur/Usd has reclaimed 1.2220 after post-Ifo selling stopped short (marginally) of breaching yesterday’s base and is back above the 100 DMA (1.2210).

subject: Fixed/FX latest: 3% resistance finally yields, and Usd/Jpy takes out 109.00
content: It remains rather disconnected in terms of a pure Dollar rise on rampant US Treasury yields, but as 10 year cash physically crosses the 3% threshold and 2 years prints 2.5% ahead of the auction, Usd/Jpy has responded to the differential and surpassed 109.00 on the way to eclipsing the 100 DMA just above the figure and peak so far around 109.15.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 24th April 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European equities opened on the backfoot, but have seen more choppy trade since (Eurostoxx 50 flat) amid relatively light newsflow thus far
  • DXY has cleared another key upside technical level amidst more widespread Dollar gains and has also eclipsed 91.000.
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US consumer confidence, housing data, APIs, and a slew of speakers

ASIA

Asia-Pac stock markets were mostly in the green with an improvement in tone seen in comparison to the lacklustre performance on Wall St where rising yields and declines in basic materials dampened sentiment. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) traded positive with Australia supported by gains in financials and energy names, while Japanese exporters benefited from a weaker JPY. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.9%) and Hang Seng (+1.3%) outperformed after a mild net liquidity injection by the PBoC, as well as press reports that China has further room to cut RRR and is likely to ease liquidity tension this week. Furthermore, Rusal shares rose by around 30% in Hong Kong on hopes of sanction relief, while the blue-chip energy and property names led the upside in the Hang Seng. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively uneventful with demand subdued amid the improvement in risk appetite, although downside was also limited as USTs nursed losses and following a relatively uneventful 2yr auction.

China has additional room to reduce RRR and repay maturing Medium-term Lending Facility loans, while it is also likely to ease liquidity tension during the week, according to reports. (China Securities Journal)

PBoC injected CNY 30bln via 7-day reverse repos for a net daily injection of CNY 30bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3229 (Prev. 6.3034)

Australian CPI QQ (Q1) 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.6%). (Newswires)

Australian CPI YY (Q1) 1.9% vs. Exp. 2.0% (Prev. 1.9%)

Australian RBA Trimmed Mean CPI QQ (Q1) 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.4%)

Australian RBA Trimmed Mean CPI YY (Q1) 1.9% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 1.8%)

GEOPOLITICAL

Iranian President Rouhani warns Trump to stay in the nuclear deal or "face severe consequences"

EU/UK/US

US Senate panel advanced Mike Pompeo nomination for Secretary of State position after US Senator Rand Paul changed his mind and voted to confirm Mike Pompeo for the Secretary of State position, although Pompeo still needs to be confirmed by the full Senate. (Newswires)

UK PM May dismissed calls for a confidence vote regarding the customs union, (FT) This comes ahead of May facing a Cabinet split over a customs deal with the EU when she meets senior ministers on Tuesday ahead of a key Commons vote next month that could determine her future as leader. EQUITIES

European equities opened on the backfoot, but have seen more choppy trade since (Eurostoxx 50 flat) amid relatively light newsflow thus far. Looking at the sectors, energy names are outperforming amid the rise in oil prices. Telecom names lag behind with Telenor (-2.5%) weighing on the sector following weak earnings. In terms of stock specifics, William Hill (-14.0%) are at the foot of the Stoxx 600 after reports that UK Chancellor Hammond has accepted the proposal for GBP 2 fixed-odd betting terminals limit. Semi-conductor names took a hit following earnings from AMS (-9.0%) with Dialog Semiconductors (-6.0%) and STMicroelectronics (-1.6%) lower in sympathy. On the flip side SAP (+3.2%) shares are higher post-earnings while BP (+1.4%) shares are fuelled by an upgrade at Goldman Sachs.

FX

DXY

The index has cleared another key upside technical level amidst more widespread Dollar gains and has also eclipsed 91.000 to expose fair resistance around 91.526 ahead of a stronger chart hurdle circa 91.751.

NZD/AUD

The Kiwi has really taken fright amidst the latest Usd leg-up, but also as cross flows vs its antipodean neighbour weigh heavily. Nzd/Usd is hovering precariously just above 0.7100, while Aud/Nzd is only a few pips below 1.0700 after accelerated buying (stops and orders) on a break of 1.0660. Relative ‘outperformers’ among the G10 community, but still weak overall vs the Usd and well off recent peaks, as Usd/Cad dips back below 1.2850 and Cable holds above the top of a support band extending from 1.3920-1.3890.

Flat or softer than anticipated CBI industrial orders depending on the consensus forecast used in comparison to the actual figure coincided with a tepid uptick in Gilts off a fresh 121.17 Liffe low, -5 ticks vs +20 ticks at best, but still lagging a bit vs Bunds that remain a few ticks in positive territory. In truth the 10 year EU benchmarks are relatively rangebound in low key/volume trade after the more pronounced price action and moves yesterday, and awaiting bigger events/calendar items for further direction as USTs idle sideways ahead of the US open.

content: Gilts on a firmer footing in line with fixed peers within a 121.24-39 range vs Monday’s 121.22 Liffe close, and largely due to a bout of consolidative trade after the bear steepening that pushed yields up to fresh multi-month peaks and 10 year USTs to virtual touching distance of the 3% handle. Short Sterling futures not looking that stable with the strip narrowly mixed around parity, but the front end has markedly outperformed and rallied sharply in wake of last week’s UK data disappointments and the subsequent scale down in May BoE rate hike expectations amidst less hawkish remarks from Governor Carney, who incidentally was reported to be attending an event later today, but calendars may have got wires crossed and ahead of themselves with the actual date in question May 24th. Bunds: more consolidation off Mondays lows
content: A broad reprieve for core bonds as the benchmark 10 year US Treasury yield backs off from the psychological 3% mark after getting to within a fraction of 1 basis point from the key level at one stage yesterday. Bunds opened 8 ticks firmer at 157.88, and after an early wobble (to a 157.81 low) have gathered a bit more upside momentum to test the resolve of offers/resistance around 158.00 (topping out at 157.98). Looking ahead, Germany’s April Ifo survey is expected to reveal significantly weaker climate and current conditions readings so any significant deviation from consensus will likely provide more impetus/direction, while Schatz supply goes head to head with the first of this week’s US auctions as the 2 year yield differential blows out to 300+ bp. In terms of speakers, ECB’s Villeroy delivers a lecture in London ahead of Thursday’s policy meeting.

subject: Barclays on todays Eurozone and UK Supply
content:
Germany Schatz auction

In outright terms 2y Germany yields have sold off around 6bps over the past month, while vs. OIS the bond has cheapened around 0.5bp over the same period. Cross market 2y Germany has cheapened 4.5bp vs. France and just under 4bp vs. Finland in the past month leaving yield give ups vs. the core at multiyear lows here.

Italian linkers

This has potential to supply a reasonable quantity of Italian duration to the market. There were some modest signs of concession in the BTP€i32 yesterday while the BTP€i28 was a slight relative value outperformer.

UK linker auction

There were no specific developments in the issue yesterday. From a relative value perspective, Barlcays do not think the bond offers particularly interesting value and as a quite recently issued bond it faces several more reopening events. Supply for the rest of the quarter is scheduled to be notably shorter on the real yield curve, which should ensure a reasonable reception for the auction. Given that long linker breakevens are at the cheaper end of their recent range, there is also potential for interest to emerge on this basis.

subject: BOND AUCTION PREVIEW: Supply today comes from Italy, UK, Germany and US
content:
AUCTION PREVIEW: EUR 1.5-2.0bln 2020 CTZ and EUR 2.5-3.5bln 1.3% 2020 and 1.25% 2032 BTPei auctions

Italy will reopen its March 2020 CTZ for EUR 1.5-2.0bln today, before Friday’s BTP auction. Please see below for previous auction history. Italy is also set to auction inflation linked supply with results for both lines expected after 1000BST (0500EDT)

Source: UBS

ECB 7-DAY MRO

Last week, the ECB allotted EUR 1.6bln at its 7-day operation. A poll of 18 money market traders expects the ECB to allot EUR 1.7bln this week. The announcement is expected at 1030BST (0530EDT).

AUCTION PREVIEW: GBP 750mln 0.125% I/L Gilt

The UK reopens its 0.125% linker for GBP 750mln, taking the total amount to GBP 6.5bln. The bidding deadline is 1030BST with results expected a few minutes past the bidding deadline. IFR are constructive on the auction, saying that the on a relative value basis, the 2048 line offers around 1bps of value on the 2047 and 2037 fly, adding that the modest size should deliver a drama free result.

AUCTION PREVIEW: German EUR 4bln 0% 2020 Schatz

Germany reopens its EUR 4bln March 2020 Schatz with the bidding deadline at 1030BST (0530EDT) and results expected shortly after.

They last sold this Schatz on March 20th, selling EUR 4bln with a B/C of 1.41, yield of -0.59% and retention of 19.0%. Please see below for recent auction history.

IFR expect the auction to go well given the limited amount of high quality duration coming into a defensive market. They note good concession as European bonds have eased from the previous tap in March while there is also good market concession to OATs and DSLs, however, two of the last three Schatz auctions have been technically uncovered.

Source: UBS

AUCTION PREVIEW: US USD 32bln 2-year notes

ISSUANCE: US Treasury will auction a total of $113bln this week ($32bln 2-year notes on Tuesday; $35bln 5-year notes on Wednesday; $17bln 2-year FRN on Wednesday; $29bln 7-year notes on Thursday. Net supply is implied at $3.6bln given that $109.4bln maturing at the mid-month settlement. Analysts also note that over the next month, gross supply (including next week’s auction of $73blnin 3s, 10s, 30s) is around $169bln, with large cashflows due, estimated around $208bln. Traders are also cognizant of the Q2 refunding announcement on 2/May, where the US Treasury may raise the size of auction issuance, according to some analysts.

2-YEAR PREVIEW: Since the previous auction cycle, 2-year yields have printed a series of fresh cyclical highs, though parts of the curve have not kept up with the rise in the short-end, resulting in fresh cyclical narrows for the likes of 2s30s. some policymakers have warned that the curve could invert (Fed’s non-voter Bullard suggested it could happen within six-months), which could portend a recession; others, however, note that the cyclical dynamic is different this time given the activist monetary policy that central bank’s engaged in through the great financial crisis, which saw them build bond holdings. Goldman Sachs, for instance, does not see an inversion in this cycle. Either way, this cheapening of the 2s sector on the curve is likely to be a positive for the auction. Elsewhere, recent auction of 2s have been lukewarm, generally stopping through or tailing by +/- 1bps on average over the last six and 12-months. There has also been attention on dealer participation, which has been edging up over the last few auctions amid declining direct and indirect participation.

Source: TD Securities.

subject: UBS Weekly FX Flows: CHF most bid, EUR net sold
content:
• CHF most bought in G10 space on a normalised basis, as corporates recorded the largest buying interest among all client groups and EUR/CHF nears 1.20
  • EUR sold for a third straight week with the heaviest selling coinciding with the inflation print on Wednesday
  • USD registered buying interest for a third week in a row
  • GBP also experienced inflows despite weak CPI data and dovish statements from the BoE
  • AUD was bought, with majority of inflows on Wednesday, coinciding with labour data release

  • SEK and JPY were marginally bid, with investor net flows oscillating throughout the week
  • NZD was the most sold currency, seeing net outflows for the first time in five weeks as inflation fell
  • NOK was marginally sold for the third week in a row

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Highlights include stories from Deutsche Bank, Sanofi and Santander
content:
24th April 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia-Pac stock markets were mostly in the green with an improvement in tone seen in comparison to the lacklustre performance on Wall St where rising yields and declines in basic materials dampened sentiment. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.8%) traded positive with Australia supported by gains in financials and energy names, while Japanese exporters benefited from a weaker JPY. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+2.1%) and Hang Seng (+1.1%) outperformed after a mild net liquidity injection by the PBoC, as well as press reports that China has further room to cut RRR and is likely to ease liquidity tension this week. Furthermore, Rusal shares rose by around 30% in Hong Kong on hopes of sanction relief, while the blue-chip energy and property names led the upside in the Hang Seng.

DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asia-Pac stock markets were mostly in the green with an improvement in tone seen in comparison to the lacklustre performance on Wall St
content:
• Asia-Pac stock markets were mostly in the green with an improvement in tone seen in comparison to the lacklustre performance on Wall St
  • USD remained firm following the recent advances and higher yields with the DXY in close proximity to the 91.00 level
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German IFO, UK borrowing data, APIs and a slew of speakers

ASIA

Asia-Pac stock markets were mostly in the green with an improvement in tone seen in comparison to the lacklustre performance on Wall St where rising yields and declines in basic materials dampened sentiment. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.8%) traded positive with Australia supported by gains in financials and energy names, while Japanese exporters benefited from a weaker JPY. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+2.1%) and Hang Seng (+1.1%) outperformed after a mild net liquidity injection by the PBoC, as well as press reports that China has further room to cut RRR and is likely to ease liquidity tension this week. Furthermore, Rusal shares rose by around 30% in Hong Kong on hopes of sanction relief, while the blue-chip energy and property names led the upside in the Hang Seng. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively uneventful with demand subdued amid the improvement in risk appetite, although downside was also limited as USTs nursed losses and following a relatively uneventful 2yr auction.

China has additional room to reduce RRR and repay maturing Medium-term Lending Facility loans, while it is also likely to ease liquidity tension during the week, according to reports. (China Securities Journal)

PBoC injected CNY 30bln via 7-day reverse repos for a net daily injection of CNY 30bln. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3229 (Prev. 6.3034)
 

UK

UK PM May dismissed calls for a confidence vote regarding the customs union, (FT) This comes ahead of May facing a Cabinet split over a customs deal with the EU when she meets senior ministers on Tuesday ahead of a key Commons vote next month that could determine her future as leader. (Telegraph) Furthermore, the House of Lords voted by a majority of 77 to keep the fundamental charter of EU rights in force after Britain leaves the EU with 10 Conservative voting with the opposition. (Guardian)

 

FX

USD remained firm following the recent advances and higher yields with the DXY in close proximity to the 91.00 level. The strength in the greenback saw its counterparts languish in which EUR/USD briefly slipped below 1.2200 and with GBP/USD a distance from the 1.4000 handle, while PBoC also weakened the reference rate in response and USD/JPY gained a solid footing above 108.50. Elsewhere, antipodeans were subdued with AUD/USD choppy following mixed CPI data which remained below the 2%-3% target range and further supported calls for the RBA to maintain a wait-and-see stance, while NZD underperformed its counterpart across the Tasman on technical buying after AUD/NZD broke through resistance at 1.0660 and the prior week’s highs to print its best level in a month.

Australian CPI QQ (Q1) 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.6%). (Newswires)
Australian CPI YY (Q1) 1.9% vs. Exp. 2.0% (Prev. 1.9%)
Australian RBA Trimmed Mean CPI QQ (Q1) 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.4%)
Australian RBA Trimmed Mean CPI YY (Q1) 1.9% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 1.8%)
 

COMMODITIES 

Commodities were mixed in which WTI crude futures marginally extended on the prior day’s rebound and attempted a reclaim of the 69.00/bbl level on several occasions overnight. Elsewhere, gold was lacklustre and held near 1-month lows amid a firm greenback, while copper found support amid heightened risk appetite in its largest consumer China which also helped Shanghai steel and Dalian iron ore prices recover from early pressure triggered by a slump in Shanghai aluminium at the open.

Iran's oil minister Zanganeh stated that if crude prices continue to rise, there will be no need to extend the OPEC/Non-OPEC pact. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

US Defence Secretary Mattis said there are a lot of reasons to believe that negotiations with North Korea will be fruitful. (Newswires)

US Acting Secretary of State Sullivan said US President Trump wants a stronger Iran deal if possible and repeats has concerns with current deal. (Newswires)
 

US

US 10yr T-Notes futures settled 7 ticks lower at 119-10+.  Treasuries closed modestly lower on the day, amid quiet trade, with most of the action concentrated on the front end and belly of the curve, with both 5s30s and 2s30s widening by c.2bp. The 10-year Treasury yield is consolidating a shade beneath 3.00% amid growing debt supply and faster inflation, printing recent highs at 2.9980 the highest since January 2014.

White House Legislative Director Short said that it remains an option when asked if President Trump will leave NAFTA. (Newswires)

US Senate panel advanced Mike Pompeo nomination for Secretary of State position after US Senator Rand Paul changed his mind and voted to confirm Mike Pompeo for the Secretary of State position, although Pompeo still needs to be confirmed by the full Senate. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID SESSION UPDATE: Asia shrugs off lacklustre Wall St performance with most bourses positive
content:
Asia-Pac stock markets are mostly in the green with an improvement in tone seen in comparison to the lacklustre performance on Wall St where rising yields and declines in basic materials dampened sentiment. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.7%) are positive with Australia supported by gains in financials and energy names, while Japanese exporters benefit from a weaker JPY. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+1.8%) and Hang Seng (+1.0%) are the outperformers after a mild net liquidity injection by the PBoC and amid press reports China is likely to ease liquidity tension this week. Furthermore, Rusal shares are higher by over 28% in Hong Kong on hopes of sanction relief, while the blue-chip energy and property names have led the upside in the Hang Seng.

In FX markets, USD remains firm following the recent advances and rising yields with the DXY within close proximity of the 91.00 level to the upside. The strength in the greenback saw its counterparts languish in which EUR/USD briefly slipped below 1.2200 and with GBP/USD a distance from the 1.4000 handle, while PBoC also weakened the reference rate in response and USD/JPY gained a solid footing above 108.50. Elsewhere, antipodeans are subdued with AUD/USD choppy following mixed CPI data which remained below the 2%-3% target range and further supported calls for the RBA to maintain a wait-and-see stance, while NZD underperformed its counterpart across the Tasman on technical buying as AUD/NZD broke through resistance at 1.0660 and the prior week’s highs to print its best level in a month.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are relatively uneventful with demand subdued amid the improvement in risk appetite, although downside is also limited as USTs nurse losses and with a 2yr auction scheduled later.
